thinking.disposable_income: Pullman has a median income of $54,755, with 45.8% households earning less than $50,000. The per capita income of $32,327 suggests moderate disposable income, making residents sensitive to cost increases
thinking.discretionary_consumption: Given the income distribution and household sizes, discretionary spending is limited for many residents. Higher sales taxes would significantly impact the 45.8% of households earning below $50,000
thinking.accessibility: 64% drive alone and 17.6% use transit for commuting. 16.1% have no vehicle, while 49.8% have one vehicle. Good transit access is important for both car-free households and single-car families
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower sales tax (0.5%) to protect discretionary spending. 2. Balance moderate transit fares ($1.25) with service quality. 3. Support driving fee of $0.50 to improve transit without excessive burden on drivers. 4. Consider high transit usage among no-vehicle households. 5. Factor in majority of single-vehicle households who need both driving and transit options. Selected policies optimize travel times while maintaining affordability
